He might try to collect a crowd in a temple, or some other place of public resort, or he might get the loan of a room from a wealthy patron, or he might wait to be asked at a private party. The contempt with which Juvenal alludes to the public reciter, the bitterness with which he speaks ¹of dependence upon a patron for the mere use of a hall, are slight reasons sor supposing that he addressed select audiences, invited probably by circular, and meeting under a roof. There is evidence that recitations were

p very frequent in Rome, and that the necessity of attending them was felt to be agrave social infliction. Pliny, who mentions on one occasion that there had been public readings every day in the month of April, lets us know that a great many hearers went reluctantly and did not stay out the reading, and apolo- gises on another occasion for going himself, on the ground that he was r'epaying a friend for attentions of the same kind. Pliny, however, records also that during a time of political liberty, probably under Nerva or Trajan, recitations became popular, and men were found to recite three days running, and could get audiences to listen to them, not, he remarkS, because there is more eloquence than there used to be, but because it is possible to write with greater freedom, and so with greater pleasure to oneself. Juvenal's Satires-teeming with allusions that would be caught up in a moment, and breathing the spirit of aristocratic feeling as it lingered in the best sets-are pre· cisely the kind of literature that would be fashionable in such breathing-times as Pliny describes.
